Chapter XI
Surveying Incidents, continued-Job Stickney or There's Many a Slip between the Cup and the Lip.
Saturday, Sept. 21st.-Surveyed another Island.  The 22d being Sunday remained in camp.  The 23d and 24th and 25th were occupied in finishing up the Islands, and on the 26 removed camp to Squirrel Grove against a very strong head wind.  High wind and a severe rain prevailed on the 27th, which gave us a complete drenching.  The 28 was very pleasant, with a fresh breeze from the North West.
Monday, 30th.-Removed camp to within four miles of Saginaw River.  Passed Bear river, which is twenty yards wide and twelve feet deep at its mouth.  Its course is principally through low, wet prairies.
Wednesday, Oct 1st.-In consequence of a thunder storm, yesterday and today were spent in our tents listening to the yarns of the men.  One of which is good enough to be repeated.
Job Stickney was a man of universal genius and such an one as can be born and brought up only in Yankeedom.  There was nothing that he could not do-from whittling out a toothpick with his jack-knife to building a house with a broad axe and handsaw.  His favorite saying was, "That the world owed him a living, and he would have it some how or other;" and he lived up to his phi-

of all my sins in as little about the quickest thrice, and wish myself to hum agin, then I didn't, that's all.  I was hauled a board, howsoever, and soon on the road to mine-I mean York-but its sin-on-emus, I guess.
'I had never been aboard on a steamboat before, and so soon as I was dry, I went pryin' about and peekin' into one place and another, to see what I could find out in her fixin's and gearin's to speculate on.  The hands on the boat soon found out that I was green 'un.  In the boiler room I got my face well smouched; the cooks pinned a dish cloth to my back-the porters and hands knocked me about as so much lumber-the bar-keeper treat me to rum and salt-I got a jet of steam in my face while investigatin' the mysteries of the engine room, and was knocked down by a surly old ?hunks? for lookin' over his shoulder to see what he was writin' about.  The wind blew pretty considerable on the Sound, and I was pesky sick; so I was considerably elevated when the boat touched the wharf in York, and hastened ashore-but I was again too fast in my calculations, for in jumpin' I lit right sider a basket of eggs an old woman had gist deposited on the deck.
"Gist pay me for them are eggs," says she.
"I haint go no money," says I; and I started off inter a run.  She cried out, and the people on the dock cried out, and the men on the

losophy, although with no very marked success, as will be seen.  But I will let him tell his own story, without any of the usual flourishes of an authors imagination.
'I was born,' said he, 'in the town of Danbury, Connecticut-brought up under tight reins, and when I was of age, away I went, to seek my fortin in the world alone-not even stoppin' to bid a fond mother good-bye, or receive and blessin' from a good old father.  Ever since that time I have been there tumbled about in the lap of fortin', sometimes with one side up, and sometimes with to'ther, but always finding myself thar' in the end.  You have hearn say that "there is many a slip between the cup and the lip;" and that's just what I have experienced all my life-never mind, there is some fun in this life yet and I'll shake it out.  Well, the first thing I did after vamousin' was to steer right for New Haven, where I visited about all the shops and stores in the place for a situation, without success, bein' told in more nor one that they had gist got a clerk.  Well, thinks I, I'll go to York; and as it was near upon the time for the boat to start, I streaked it for the wharf, and ariv' gist as she was swingin' off.  I give a spring, and, kerswous I went into the briney deep.  I didn't know how to swim, and came as near "uncoiling this mortal shiffle," as Shakespeare says, as I want to for a spell, and I tell you what, of I didn't think

was follerin' their example-I became desperate and took liberties with other people's property.  I didn't like the game, no how, but the world owes man a livin', and if he can't git it honestly, why he must git it.  (A very foolish [retrie?]).  Byne by I came across a well dressed feller who wanted help, he said, and asked me if I could write.
"Oh! yes, says I, "I've been to schull, and through college too!"
"That's right.  But you don't look as if you had ever seen the inside of a college," says he, peekin' through my gosamer hat, and inter my goos? deer coat.
"Well, you see," says I, to explain, "I was desperate hard up a spell ago, and went inter the back door of old Columbia to see what I could find worth appropriating, when they kicked me out at the front door."
'Well, this chap wanted me to use my larnin' in counterfetin' notes, and offered strong inducements, but I couldn't go that, no how, and departed.  I then worked my way to Albany, and got aboard on a canal boat - follered the business three years, and then fell in love with an all fired pretty gal in Rome.  I sparked up to her considerable strong for a long spell, but some how or other I couldn't git the hang of the thing so as to come the sentimental.  She was an oprhan, and

4
boat cried out, and they all cried out- "Stop that vagabond!" but on I darted up the street.  Howsomever, I wasn't fast enough to escape the shower of broken eggs that was sent after me; and if I wasn't a little the most curious critter you ever did see, then my name's not Job Stickney.  Howsomever I went ahead like a high-pressure locomotive, and as soon as I got out of harm's way, I set about tidyin' myself up-but it was an awful job, I tell you.  As soon as it was done, I went right straight to work to get a place.  After lookin' about considerable, I at last found an old gentleman who was polite enough to ask me where my recommend was, as he wanted a porter.  Now, I hadn't no recommend, but I jist up with my hand an' strokin' down my face, "Here," says I.  He seemed kind of tickled with the answer, and said he'd give me a trial; so I off coat and went to work.  I stopped with him a spell, and saved some money, which I was goin' to lay out for a farm at the west, when jist as I thought I had enough, and calculated to draw it from the bank where I had put it for safe keepin', the peskey thing busted up, and I lost it all.  My boss had all his money thar too, and he busted up, so I was jist thar agin and ready for a fresh start.  But I couldn't find nothing to do - was turned out of several boarding houses for not payin'- my toes stuck out of my shoes - my elbers and knees

7

  "Because I'm engaged to another," says she.  "I thought you didn't care about me, Job, as you never said you did, and Tom Jones was so pressin' - and next to you I liked him best that I consented.  It isn't twenty minutes since I promised to be his wife tomorrow."
  "Oh! so soon!" I cried; and givin' her one last fond look, I mizzled out of the house.  The cup had again slipped from my lips.  I squared accounts with the capting of the canal boat, and made tracks for Buffalo - shipped aboard of a schooner bound for Erie - was wrecked off Dunkirk, and got ashore with a bruised head and empty pockets, my money goin' to the bottom with the schooner.  I took my knife and went to work mekin' axe helves, picked up a few dollars, and set off afoot for Erie, payin' my way as I went by mendin' clocks, rakes, wheelbarrows, carts, threshin' machines, and doin' any other odd job that turned up.  There I made some money by hardwork as a chopper - didn't see why other folks should be gettin' rich faster nor I by speculation - took Mr. Prince's advice and tried my hand in the [?morens?] [?multiranlis?] business, and in one month found myself jist back thar agin, ready for another fresh start.
  'Next, I went to Toledo - driv the stage a spell for Woodworth and Co; and again saved some money to buy a farm with - but the fever and na-

6
had some money, and I thought she had a kind of snickerin' after me.  At last I made a desperate push and propounded the interrogatory.

  "Job," says she, "you are a nice young man."  My heart began to go ker-chunk! ker-chunk! ker-chunk!  "And I don't know nobody I should like better for a husband."  I was in a perfect fever and [ager?] of happiness.  "You are a smart young man, and appear to be both industrious and prudent; and that's what every young woman of sense wants in a husband - except them as is brought up in the aristocracies who think more on moustaches and fine coats" - my excitabilities had got up to the bilin' pint - "and I don't know anyone I should like better-"
  I threw myself upon my knees before her, tuck her lily white hand and smacked it smartly - but I couldn't account for the large tears that ran like a mill stream down her cheeks.  She wiped them off, and continued:
  "I never see a young man who could make me so happy, but -"  and she stopped.
  "But what?" says I.
  "But - but - but "
  "For mercy's sake!  what's the matter ?" says I, feelin' kinder anxious.
  "I cannot marry you, Job."
  I was struck all in a heap.  "If you love me, why not marry me?" said I, tremblin' like a horse with the founder.

9
twelve to twenty two feet deep.  The fifth and sixth we were detained in camp by rain.  On the sixth surveyed the river although still stormy.

  Tuesday 7th - During the day as yesterday.  In the evening I found a remarkably curious insect, which emitted a most brilliant light.  It was about an inch long, and three tenths of an inch in circumference.  On each side was a row of nine beautiful spots of a yellow tinge from which it emitted its light.  Between these two rows, on the back were two stripes of a yellowish purple color, which alternated with three others of a brownish hue.
  Wednesday, 8th - Passed the Kancholia river; which is about fifty yards in width and seven feet deep; and, unlike most of the rivers of the bay, has high banks at its mouth, possessing advantages for mills of the finest kind.  The land is covered with pine, fur &c.
  Thursday, 9th  Remained in camp and took observations with secstant.   North latitude 95º 17' 5" and distant from Fort Gratiot 167 miles.
  Friday 10th  Surveyed nearly all day through a marsh, and crossed Potatoe river two miles from the Kancholia.  Here we had a hearty laugh at the expanse of Lieut. P.   Being commandant of the expedition it would be natural to suppose, that a mind like his would - as he did - choose the least arduous part of the work, namely,

8
ger turk hold on me, shook all the teeth out of my mouth, the hair off my head, and the money out of my pockets.  As Toledo had made me a shaker, I made up my mind to go in for the Shakin' Quakers - joined them at New Lebanon - had some fun with their peculiarities 'till I got well, and then vamoused - dove inter the woods of Indiana, and grubbed stumps - laid up five hundred dollars, and then started for a land office - entered a quarter section, and looked around and purchased stock and tools - went back, built a house, and considered myself settled - had a fine crop of wheat growin', and then like a darned fool, sold out to an old chap, who tuck a fancy to my location, for three times morn it cost me.  Thought I'd play the gentleman a spell before buyin' another farm - went to Chicago - got inter the hands of some men smarter than myself - was fleeced, and here I am jist thar agin, takin' another fresh start."

  Job looked as if he could and would, take many more fresh starts before he got through the world.
  Thursday, Oct 2nd - Surveyed through water, knee deep, to the camp.
  Friday, 3rd - Struck our tents and steered for Saginaw river, where we encamped at 12 o'clock m.  This the largest river emptying into Saginaw Bay and one of the largest in Michigan.  It is from a quarter to half a mile wide for some miles above its mouth, and from

11
vinced that anything I could say to Lieut. P- would have no effect, I gave him advice, which I promised would be more effective.  He determined to try it, and I took care that both officers and men should have an inkling of what was to transpire.

  It was not long before an opportunity offered.  Pototatoe river was more than ordinarily deep at the ford, and rather muddy.  We all, however, - except Lieut P-, strode in and waded across, leaving him in some astonishment at the presumption of Antoine - the Canadian - in crossing without rendering him the usual assistance.  In an angry tone he bid him, "come back and perform your duty."
  Totteringly the poor fellow entered the water with his burthen, and the Lieutenant feeling himself rather unsteady began to show strong symptoms of fear.  Just as they gained the centre, and deepest part of the stream, the Canadian for a moment swerved and then fell, head foremost into the turpid water, entirely disappearing for a moment and then rising, spluttering and blowing like a couple of porpoises.  I never saw a more ludicrous sight in my life than that presented by the pompous Lieutenant - as, with arms extended at an angle of about forty five degrees with the body, his head projected forward, the water streaming

10
removing camp and using the theodolite, both of which required very little mental and no bodily exertion.  In performing the first he usually took particular delight in going so far ahead of the surveyers that they were often obliged - after their day's work was done - to walk or row several miles to the camp; and occasionally the men - worn out as they were -would be set to work chopping wood and building fires, of an enormous size, in front of his tent to keep off the mosquitoes.  Sometimes we would have to give up all idea of finding him and stretch ourselves without supper upon the damp ground and sleep, if we could.

  Among the Canadians who formed the larger portions of the operatives was one of the gigantic proportions, but of a very mild disposition, making him a very ready and willing instrument in the hands of Lieut. P -, and appropriate to the duty assigned to him.  This was to carry the Lieutenant on his back over every fordable stream -  Every one else wading over, like men.  The frequent occurrence of this task made the Canadian, at last, the butt of his companions, every man of whom would have sooner abandoned the expedition, and thrown up their pay, than submit to such a dagradation.  After enduring their jeers as long as it was possible he came to me in hopes that I could in some way, relieve him, as I had before done for others of the party.  Con-

13

  Thursday, 16th-  Notwithstanding the severity of the weather and the caution of Capt. Marras,  Lieut. P- resolved to proceed.  The attempt to cross the bar at the mouth of the river proved abortive as the sea ran so high that the boats were soon filled and with much difficulty we succeeded in getting back.  Wind S.E.
  Friday, 17th  Wind continued to blow a gale, and snow fell in the afternoon in large flakes.  The wind changed on the 18th to the north and continued violent.  Amused ourselves with a game of ball.
  Sunday, 19th-  The wind having abated in some measure we proceeded as far as point au Chene, but unable to double it were obliged to land.
  Monday, 20th - Proceeded homeward; wind high from the east.  Passed Point au Chapeau, Sugar Loaf Point and Pidgeon river and landed for the night two miles south of Point au Barque.  
  The rest of the journey was boisterous and disagreeable without any thing worthy of note.
  From the time of my return until the middle of January of the following year I devoted myself to looking after my mother's business.  Cousin Tom - roaring Tom - of Kalamazoo, paid us a New Year's visit and on his return I was induced to accompany him.  We traveled on horseback without any adventure worth recording, except that on the last night, with the thermometer 32º below zero, we came very near be-

12
from his hair over his face, and his clothes adhering tightly to his long, lank person, he came gulphing and puffing to the shore, looking as if he could eat a whole platoon by way of relish.  This one dose effectually cured him.

  Sunday 12th.  Yesterday and to-day remained in camp.  Several canoe loads of Indians passed, on their way to Saginaw to receive the money annually paid to them by our government.  A strange scene usually takes place on these occasions.  After receiving his silver the Indian is met at the door by men, who are employed by different traders in Indian merchandize, who seize upon him and a tussel ensuse for possession of the money.  The trader whose agent is successful pockets the specie and the Indian is obliged to purchase at his store.  Sometimes the Indian succeeds in escaping with his treasure; in which case he trades with whom he pleases.
  Monday, 13. -  Removed camp six miles - and on the 14th finished the survey for the season at 9 o'clock A.M.  The rest of the day being rainy and boisterous all hands were occupied in getting ready for our homeward voyage.
  Wednesday, 15th. -  Launched our boats at daybreak and by seven o'clock were under way.  Passed Point au Sable, Kancholin, Saginaw, Bear and Thread rivers and camped at Crooked river after a hard day's work.

15
ihood to labor through my pen impressions of human life - of this sketch, to deter you for a moment from prosecuting your seige to a final capitulation, for the fortress of woman's affections is well worth all the ammunitions expended for its conquest, notwithstanding it sometimes blows up and scatters ruin around, or, like a cannon ball, goes off with a flash and buries itself in oblivion.  But I am forgetting my subject, and giving advice which may, per chance, resemble the powder and end in smoke.  So to my yarn.

  In the village of K-- all the lads and lassies were - as in all new country towns where they are not very numerous and where fashion had made no advance - on the most familiar terms.  There kisses did not go by favor, neither was a man turned out of doors and refused apple pie for supper for taking one whenever he could get an opportunity; neither was it a disgrace to sit when the knee of a beaux and join in a chorus from Watt's and Rippon, or in a duet on two lips.  Of course people who were so unsophisticated in these matters could hardly be expected to be otherwise in the little et ceteras appertaining to the etiquette of polished society, for heart and fashion cannot flourish upon the same stem.
   Being the guest of a family the younger por-

14
ing frozen to death, or rather cousin Tom did, for I actually suffered very little, although less warmly clad.  This I have always considered was owing to the fact of my strictly temperate habits.  At every stage of our journey cousin Tom would regale himself with a stiff hot toddy while I took nothing but the coldest of water.  My kind old uncle and aunt E- and sweet cousins Ann and Mary received us with open arms and affectionate greeting, and during the fortnight I remained with them treated me like a prince.  Good, kind cousin Ann has been long an angel in heaven, and sweet, affectionate Mary is still I hope the loving wife of a loving husband.  While here two very amusing incidents occurred to which I will devote the next chapter.
Chapter XII
A Backwood's Wedding - The Speculator and His victim

  Ah!  does not that word -'wedding' - recall a happy event of bye-gone days; or perhaps you have never enjoyed the blessed companionship of one of earth's brightest petals; but then you may be in expectation of one, and in that case, what a thrill of joyous rapture must be thine in the contemplation; but, harken! do not suffer the perusal - if you have the hard-

17
trudge the whole distance on foot.  I shall not stop to describe how one of my fair charges lost a shoe in a mud hole, or how another mistook a large puddle that lay in our path for a dry piece of terra firma, and in springing into it lost her centre of gravity, and very composedly seated herself in the element; or how a third tore her ringlets out by running into a bramble bush, for they were "harem-scarem" girls and would do just as they pleased, notwithstanding my remonstrances, but let us go directly into the festive hall and "peruse" the joyous assembly of republicans.  We won't be too censorious, however, for that would be showing a want of politeness.

  After going through the preliminaries of pulling off a pair of muddy overshoes with a fine pair of kid gloves, for fear of soiling a clean pair of hands, hanging up my hat and cloak in the hall, and arranging every thing about the person in "apple-pie order," I was ushered - not exactly by an usher of the black rod, but of a black face, into a small room densly crowded with guests bobbing up and down in a cotillion.  Having to pass through the middle of a set, I came very near being upset by the hoppers in their "forwards" and "backs."  We had arrived late, and the ceremony had been performed so I lost, as I was informed, the most

16
tion of which was composed of the gentler sex, it necessarily became my duty, as it was my pleasure, to accompany them to all the merry makings that took place in the neighborhood; and as it was at that season of the year when the white mantel of Jack Frost lay pretty heavily upon the ground, I usually bundled them into a crockery crate fixed upon runners made of hickory poles - a species of carryall commonly denominated at the west a jumper' - and which answered a very good purpose in the absence of the legitimate sleigh; and even better, as I could give them an occasional tumble in a snowbank without fear of injury either to the vehicle or to their sweet little limbs; and I assure you I suffered no opportunity to present itself without indulging in this practical joke, it was such capital sport to see the gay creatures scramble up, and hear their merry peals of laughter at any little catastrophe that might occur during their efforts to regain their feet.  The young ladies of the village were not all, however, of the same sensible stamp as those whom it was my good fortune to gallant, as the sequel will show.

   It was on a night very unlike those I have mentioned that I was invited to attend a wedding.  Owing to a "warm spell" the snow had disappeared, and a drenching rain during the day had made the roads impassable for any kind of vehicle and consequently we were obliged to

19
was Piper, you see - "don't ye pipe too long on that instrument, if you please; he! he! he!" gave me a push that might have caused me a closer acquaintance with the floor, had I not saved myself by grasping the lady's arm.  But the force was such that I could not prevent a more awkward catastrophe and I came plump into her lap.  The laughter occasioned by the accident restored the bridegroom's good humor, - which at first had vanished, and a storm appeared brewing - and he remarked: 

  "Well, Mr Piper, I'll excuse ye this time, but yer mustn't be comin' yer city fashions too strong here agin', or ye may have wuss handling.  The fellers have a right to kiss the gals just as much as they please; but after they is married, none but their old man has a right."
  I apologized, and retired to make room for other visitors who were pressing forward to gain audience.  Not feeling disposed to again attempt a passage through the dancers, I took up my position near the fireplace, leaning my elbow upon the mantel and my head upon my hand, in rather a pensive mood.  There was not more than a cord of wood blazing away upon the hearth, but my position soon became uncomfortable - the perspiration began to start from my forehead, and run down my face in a perfect deluge; but there was no opportunity for for im-

18
interesting part of the evening's entertainment; the bride looked so bewitchingly charming in her maiden modesty, which vanished so exquisitely with the affirmative nod, and the bridegroom said, "I will," with such a bold and decided air, - as much as to say, "who's affraid," and meant what he said, and then he gave his newly acquired wife such a hearty smack upon its conclusion as to infect the whole company with spontaneous come-busstion, and cause such a deafening volley of percussive explosions of the true paxian stamp.

  After being used as a shuttlecock by the dancers, and rebounding from sir to miss, while each roared with laughter, as he or she gave new impulse by a hearty propulsion to my side-long movement, I at length arrived before the mistress of ceremony, who was seated in a corner near the chimney.  I made my best bow, and paid my best compliments to herself and the happy pair, who were reclining on a "sofy" near their mama, trilling and cooing like a pair of turtle doves only with a "leetle" more warmth and energy.  I interrupted their happiness by the usual congratulations and a kiss; but I dwelt too long on the latter subject to please the bridegroom, who, laying his rough hand on my shoulder remarked:  
   "I say, Mr. Piper" - I told them my name

21
and when indulged was of the most silly description.
"Very pleasant weather we have, sir."
"Why, yes, sir, if not more."
"Bad for the steam boats on the lake this fog."
"Considerable - provided they take the precaution to run into each other."
"What a dunce", I said mentally, as I turned away.  "I'll engage this young lady in the corner.  Do you enjoy dancing, Miss?"
"Why, he! he! he!  I really don't know - as I can say - as I don't; he! he! but I do love blind-man's-buff."
"It is quite an exciting game, is it not?"
"Well, I can't say as I ever got excited by it.  I shouldn't think it more'n licker."
("Humph! I'll change the subject.) Do you ever engage in literary pursuits?"
"I don't know as I ever pursued any thing, sir; and I am sure - he! he! - that I never - he! he! was engaged - he! he!"
"Oh! I meant to inquire whether you read much, Miss?"
"Oh! yes, I am considered quite a lover of books."
"Have you seen Cooper's last?"
"The cooper's last!  Why I thought it was shoemakers that used lasts.  Do coopers use them too?"

20
mediate escape; every avenue save that through the dancers was completely jamed up, and of two evils I chose rather to remain and slowly evaporate, than to run the hazard of having my neck broken by the mischievous romps.  There I stood, therefore, until, being quite roasted on one side, I was beginning to think of turning round and roasting the "goose on the other", when the dancing ceased, and gave me an opportunity of retiring into the back room, less densely populated, and where cake, whiskey toddy, "apple-sauce, and other refreshments for both "man and beast" were served up.

  An old piano, too, occupied one corner of the room, which, when not giving forth the lively notes of the dance, was used by some sentimental miss to accompany a voice with that peculiar nasal twang so perfectly indescribable, while it sang -
  "On the banks where drooped the willow,"

or,

  Oh! 'tis love, 'tis love, that rules us all completely," 

or some other love ditty of like character.

   After, the company had become tired of "tripping upon the light fantastic toe," hunt the slipper - button, button, who'se got the button? - forfeits, and such like games were resorted to, to pass away the time; but as to conversation, that was a thing of very little importance,

23
against my inclinations, I consented.  A large basket was brought in and placed in the middle of the room, upside down.  One of the most beautiful of the young ladies took a seat upon it, and all the young men, including myself, joined hands and moved around her, while she recided the supposed qualities of each as he passed.  As I came before her she pronounced the words, "and him I elect to be my knight true; wilt thou my bidding do?"

  Of course I could not refuse so charming a creature, and being perfectly ignorant of the nature of the play and their designs against me, I answered:
  "Most lovely fair one, it is for you to command, me to obey.  What thou orderest, that I will do."
  I was then directed to get into the basket, which had been turned over for the purpose; of course I obeyed.  I was covered over with the fair one's shawl, and presently I found myself lifted upon the shoulders of two of the lads, and borne three times around the room, while the young ladies chanted some kind of a hocus-pocus, the words of which I neither heard nor understood.  Soon I found myself going up a flight of stairs, while the voices gradually became fainter and fainter, and at last ceased altogether.  I ventured to poke my head out

22
"I had reference to Mr. Cooper's new novel, Miss."
"Oh! had you? No, I never read such trash.  I like history best."
"Pray, who is your favorite author, Miss?"
"What a funny questioner you are, he! he! he!  Why, the author of my being, to be sure."
"Excuse me, Miss, for not being sufficiently comprehensive; I wished to ask what histories you like best."
"Robinson Crusoe, Baron Trenk, Baron Munchausen, Children of the Abbey, Paul and Virginia and Gulliver's Travels."
"What a charming taste you have, Miss," and I bowed myself away to seek other sources of enjoyment.
Hitherto I had amused myself with the verdantsy and ignorance of my country friends, but now "a change came o'er the spirit of my" - revelries.  While I chuckled at their unsophisticatedness they were preparing to induct me into some of the mysteries of country life.  A few of the most intelligent youngsters had noticed the evident satisfaction with which I looked upon all their attempts at refinement, and were resolved to be revenged.

  I was requested to take part in a new play - a very funny one, they said - and not wishing to give offense, although somewhat

25
from the direction taken after leaving the parlors, I imagined myself in the garret of the house.  The basket was placed on the floor, some mummery gone through, each placed his hands upon my head, the basket was recovered, again mounted on their shoulders, and I was taken back to the place from whence I came.

  "When we clap our hands three times," said someone, "you must appear suddenly from the basket, and claim your lady love."
  All fears of a practical joke had now vanished from my mind, and I was vain enough to suppose that some pleasing divertisement in my honor, as the stranger guest, was to meet my eyes.  The ladies - that is the young ones - now chanted a verse, and the signal was given.  I sprang up, and leaning upon the edge of the basket, gave my face as comical an expression as possible, and gazed around the room.  A tremendous burst of laughter saluted me.  The b'hoys roared and held their sides, and the g'hals, with some compunction], giggled and stuffed their mouths full of handkerchiefs, while I could hear my fair cousins whisper: "It is too bad."
  I wondered what it was "too bad," and looked about to ascertain the cause of so much mirth; but I could perceive nothing.  At

24
of the basket, but a heavy hand falling upon it rather forcibly, I drew it in again quickly.

   Up, up we went, and I puzzled my brain, to no purpose, to solve the question as to my probable destination.  I called to mind that jovial old rogue, Jack Fallstaff, and began to fear that the romps of K--- were about to give me the same treatment he received from the "Merry Wives of Windsor", and I rather calculate if I didn't feel about the smallest of a man just at that moment, then "there ain't no snaiks".
  On we went, and they appeared to be putting in practice the physician's advice, "When taken, to be well shaken," for they rolled and tumbled me about in the basket as if I were a small measure of potatoes.  With each oscilation I could hear the rogues chuckle.  I again ventured my head above the basket and exclaimed, "What the devil are you about!" but the same heavy hand obliged me to disappear as suddenly as the ghost of Hamlet's father, at the Olympic, and a voice of the "beware!" intonation bade me be quiet until I was let out.  This calmed my fears somewhat, for I concluded that if I was to be let out, I should not be thrown out, forgetting that with the Wolverines, to let out, to heave out, and to throw out, signified precisely the same thing.

   At this time the "Great Land speculation fevre" raged at its heighth throughout the West.  Villages, towns and cities sprang into existencein the course of a night - beautiful farms were laid waste and "staked out" and sold upon bond and mortgage at very cheap rates, and many wild schemes were invented for getting rich rapidly.

The little village of K__ had no sooner recovered from the excitement of the wedding than it was agitated by the appearance of a very richly dressed young man, who, with a cane in one hand, and a quizzing glass between the thumb and forefinger of the other, sauntered through the town with the air of a prince, causing the little hearts of all the young ladies to palpitate and flutter with excessive anxiety lest so pretty, agreable and fascinating a gentleman should depart without breaking one or more of their aforesaid little hearts. Mr. C__ was a tall, well proportioned individual and prided himself upon the elegance of his dress, and his exceedingly gentlemanly deportment.  He was descended from an eminent and honorable family residing in the State of New York, but unfortunately had more money in his pocket than brains in his head.

length my favorite cousin Ann came up to me and said: "They have been playing a trick upon you.  Come, let us go home.  It is shameful, and I'll never set foot within these doors again."  Her little face was crimson with anger.

  I rushed to the mirror.  I could not believe my eyes.  My hair was completely covered with flour, and my face with soot.  "Ah, ha!  that's your game, is it," thinks I.  "Let them laugh who win."  I turned from the mirror, walked deliberately up to my fair judge, and, before she could avoid me, covered her with kisses, leaving at every buss a beauty spot upon her rosey lips and cheeks.  A fair proportion of soot and flour was also deposited upon the white satin and silk vests of my late carriers and well washed in with whiskey punch.  The tables were turned.  The rogues were furious, the girls uproarious; and while the former rushed from the house with vows of vengeance upon their lips, I strutted, with begrimed face and powdered hair, through the rooms, laughing as heartily at my own odd appearance as any of them, until the hour of adjournment arrived, when I took my departure with the rest, after again kissing the bride, leaving my mark upon her and wish her a sleepless night.  Moral - You disarm ridicule, aimed at yourself, by joining in it.

Chapter XIII  Home again - Indian Calculation - Indian Dexterity - [crossed out: Taking the] Cholera - Surveying again. 

   On a bright mild morning I took my rifle, mounted my horse and biding adieu to the dear relatives in Kalamazoo set my face homeward by the way of Pigeon Prairie. The only incident of this journey worth mentioning occurred on the morning of my departure. A two hour's ride brought me to a creek. While crossing the bridge I espied two wild ducks "sitting on a rail", a short distance down the stream. I dismounted, got within range and, as they were billing", fired and put my ball through the necks of both, and I had the pleasure of sending them to my sweet cousins Ann and Mary by a traveller whom I met.  I arrived home "safe and sound" and again experienced the fact that "there is no place like home."  With the exception of a few days in the spring, until the fall, my time was devoted to my dear mother.   My leisure hours to reading, or to fishing, hunting and rambling.

The first time it visited Detroit it was not so fatal although it carried off many of the most respectable citizens.

  It was indeed a distressing heartrending sight to witness the effects of this dreadful disease.  The ghastly features, starting eyeballs, the withered frame, the horrid contortions of the whole body, and the agonizing groans defy the pen of man to depict.  In some instances the skin of the sufferer would peel from the hands, face and feet, and roll up, all gory with blood and flesh, toward the body, giving them a yet more terrible aspect.  Some would drop down dead in the streets as if struct by a thunderbolt; others would linger days and nights in all the agony of the most excruciating torture.  Some would yield up the ghost with resigned reliance upon the goodness of God - others would die giving

way to the most blasphemous imprecations against God, their homes and fellow men. Some would retain their senses to the last, calling upon their Maker for pardon of their
own sins, and instruction for their families in those things that make wise unto salvation; while others, maddened by the burning fever that consumed them, raved in delirium and
cursed the judgements of the Alwise Being who gave them life, and who alone possessed the right to deprive them of it.

He had scarce settled himself in his retired cottage when the dread destroyer summoned his beloved wife to the land of spirits; and one after another of his children were taken from him until he alone was left to acknowledge the utter impossibility of escaping from the presence of God. But how soon were these desires forgotten, and how soon I returned to the beggarly demerits of the world.  Alas!  for poor human nature. Praise be to God that His grace is sufficient for us, else where should I be now, thirty years after again closing my heart against His holy word.

  I had no sooner returned home than I was taken ill with a violent fevre in consequence of the exposure to the cold and dampness of the hole of the vessel in which our return voyage was made - for none but the officers were permitted to use the cabin,- and did not recover for three weeks.  The effects of this illness I have experienced all my life.  As soon as I recovered from this attack I resumed my duties at home and continued therein until the spring of 1835.

Chapter XIV
Taking the Census - Visit New York City.

  During the spring of this year (1835) the City clerk of Detroit having been taken ill in the midst of his arduous task of taking the census, he sent for me and requested me to finish it for him.  As he had been my teacher in days gone by, and as I felt an affectionate regard for him, I willingly consented, and commenced my labors the next day.

Return Home - A Night at Niagara - Go into business - Revisit New York - A Stump Speach
Having finished my business in New York and bid adieu to the dear friends I had made while there I left on board the steamer North America happy in my present relations and in future prospects, but regretful that I had left her behind whom I had learned to love better than self.  Each beautiful spot along the magnifi-

  In the fall of this year my dear mother sold her farm, during the prevalence of the "speculative fevre'."  On page 145 of the first volume of this manuscript I stated that it was

sold then, thinking, while copying my old journal, that it was sold when she removed into the city; but the record here shows my error.

  I received on this occasion a portion of the purchase money with which I repaired to New York city and purchased a stock of seed and agricultural implements with which to commence business for myself.
  While on this, my first, visit to New York I became acquainted with Miss Anna L Putnam, which most surely proves that "marriages are made in heaven," for previous to the

evening we met for the first time, at her aunt's house, I knew not that there was such a person in existence.  I was "smitten at first sight with her exquisite beauty, her unasuming manners, the apparent gentleness of her disposition, the loveableness of her heart and her bright intellect, and loved her from that moment.  I visited her but two weeks when
a favorable opportunity presented itself for "popping the question", which my extreme bashfullness would not otherwise have permitted me to accomplish.

place to your dying day that I had; and if you never have been there I advise you not to go.

   It was a delightful fall evening when the noble steamer Coburg set us ashore at this place.  There were four of us -  gay hearted youngsters - who, after several nights of disagreeable and uncomfortable existence in the seven by nine cabins and berths of canal and steamboats, had made up our minds for one of unaloyed and peaceful slumber on terra firma.  With some difficulty we made our way through the loose sand to the principal hotel.  We found every thing about the establishment in perfect order and cleanly, which gladdened our hearts exceedingly, for we had judged quite unfavorably of the interior by the forlorn appearance of the exterior. A substantial supper well served up made us still better satisfied with our host and his house, and we were delighted with the prospects of a good nights' rest.  
   We were assigned two rooms, each with two beds, having a light board partition between them which in many places had shrunk so as to leave craks sufficiently large for the occupants of one to see all that was going on in the other and consequently to hear every word spoken.  The sheets were as "white as the driven snow," and we laid  ourselves between them with blessings upon our lips and in our hearts for the pretty chambermaid who

54
cent Hudson which I passed renewed the regret and inspired the wish that she were with me to partake of the pleasure I enjoyed in contemplating the scenery.  I passed from Albany to Schenetada over the railroad, and at the latter place took the canal to Oswego designing to see Niagara Falls from the Canada side.  On the canal boat I became acquainted with two young Englishmen and a New Yorker who were on their way to visit the Falls, and we agreed to travel together.  At Oswego we took the steamer Coburg for Niagara. 

  Reader, (if any other eyes but my own ever see this manuscript) do you know where Niagara is situated?  I do not mean the falls - every body knows where they are - but a little, mean, low, sandy village in Upper Canada, composed principally of one story frame buildings, hogs, dogs, Canadians and their concomitants, some foreigners, and an occasional live Yankee.  It may be seen after a fortyeight hours' sail westward from Oswego in any of the Ontario steamers; and if you should get there a few minutes too late you will

have to remain there all night for being at the mouth of the Niagara river the steamers, unless freighted for Lewiston, seldom go up higher and you have to take the morning stage to Chippewa. If you have ever been there you undoubtedly have the same cause for remembering the

  A few hours ride brought us to the great falls of Niagara.  I shall not attempt to describe them.  It has been done often enough already.  I could remain but a short time, and can only say that the only sensation I felt when fully brought to view was disappointment.  After looking upon them from various points for an hour or two we left for Chippewa where we took the steamer for Buffalo.   Here I remained over night and in the morning bid a lasting farewell to my travelling companions, and after a forty-four hour's sail in the good steamer Michigan touched the wharf at Detroit.
  Arrived at home I rented a store and prepared for business; but my commencement was one of disappointment.   My goods which had been purchased in August were shipped so late that very few of them arrived before the close of navigation; but what I did receive sold rapidly and I bid fair to prosper.
  In January I received a letter from my beloved Anne's sister informing me that she was dangerously ill.  Although six feet of snow had just fallen, I immediately left for New York.   In the stage were eight other gentlemen who were as anxious to reach New York

   The remainder of the winter and the spring and summer following passed away without anything of personal interest.   The Territory, however, had been just admitted into the Union as a state, and the summer was rendered additionaly hot by a very warm canvas for Governor and other state officers.  Both Whig and democrat were exceedingly fiery, and many hard speeches were made;  one of which I took the trouble of reporting for the press as follows: -

Trip to New York - Get Married - A Stormy Time - Safe Arrival - Incidents in the Canada Rebellion.

  In the spring of 1837 the Canada rebellion

broke out and threw Detroit into excitement.
The Wolverines took great interest in the affair on
one side or the other, and every bosom was fired to
patriotic deeds or words.  I do not intend to give
an historical sketch of this affair, for that is
out of my "line of business," but merely to relate
as much of the amusing part of it as came under
my immediate observation.

  Among all the participants in this abortive

attempt along the frontier, the people on
both sides of the Detroit river were perhaps a 
little more bitter in their hatred of each other
than most others on the line of operations.
The British soldiers quartered at Sandwich and
Malden had, for a long time previous to the rupture,
rendered themselves peculiarly obnoxious
to the Wolverines by their haughty, bearing and
insolent behavior to persons who visited those
places for business or pleasure, and the latter
were too much pleased with the opportunity
thus offered for retaliation to let it pass unimproved.  
This is the reason why so many of them
took party in the contest.

  At length they became so outrageous as

A large number of young men - myself among the number volunteered their services.   We were equipped and armed according to law and quartered in the town hall.   It was about twelve o'clock at night when it came my turn to mount guard, and I took my station on one of the wharves near the ferry.   There were a large number of idlers on the wharf who were amusing themselves by bandying words with a like assemblage on the Canada side.  The night was remarkably clear and still -  so much so that, although the river at this point is full three quarters of a mile wide, every word uttered by either party was distinctly heard by the other.   When I took my station the royalists were making the night hideous with their shouts.

   Edward B-- was what the majority of terrestrial inhabitants term a happy man; for he had plenty of money, blocks of houses, a large rural domain, and a goodly share of railroad stock - and so far as that goes toward filling up the cup of bliss, he was a happy man.
   Edward B-- was also a good looking - aye, I may say a handsome man, and so far as a consciousness - and conscious he most undoubtedly was - of that fact, he was a happy man.  He was fond of the society of ladies, and in this he might have been a happy man, had it not been for - but I will not anticipate; for notwithstanding all this, I will venture to say, that a more unhappy biped never existed.   Some spell hung over him that turned all these advantages to gal [sic] and wormwood.  No man sought with more perseverance and assiduity to slip his head into the noose matrimonial than he, and yet none were ever so unsuccessful.
   Notwithstanding his acres, and houses, and monies, and rail-road stock, he could not raise a sufficient stock of affection in any fair bosom to induce it to enter into co-pardnership with him - every attempt adding only another [?ac(h)er?] to his already overburdened shoulders.

  The first year of my marriage was as prosperous as man could wish both in business and in conjugal felicity. I should have been enabled to weather the storm had it not been for the miserable banking system of the state.

 I once knew a lovely young Canadian girl

who was at all times as joyous as a lark; continually

She was remarkable for her cheerfulness, and a great

returned home to ponder on what they had heard
and seen.  So impressed was the eldest of these
ladies with the belief that the vision was an indication
of evil tidings, that she made a note
of the day and hour of its occurrence.  A few
months after - for it took a long time for events
to travel at that day - she received a letter from
her brother stating that Captain B-, the brother
of her companion on Copps' Hill, had been killed
in the battle of Tippecanoe, and buried that
morning.  She compared the date of the letter
with the note made on the day of the vision described
and found them to agree - Nov 7th 1811.

So I got along purty well for a hul year, when I thought it time to [?'sinuate?] about havin the bands denounced in the church - so says I one night, after we'd bin a leetle more lovin nor common, and she was playin with my waistcoat butting, and lookin for all the world - as I was thinkin - as ef she was expectin something extra - says I, Prudence, says I, what dew you think of my leetle shop down tew Bosting? says I.

I eloped immediately, as I gave a horselaugh, and Jack sent a rotten potatoe after me, for what he considered - in his wrath a the unceremonious departure - a very ungentlemanly proceeding.  But I cannot, without making this sketch too long, record all Jack's sayings and doings, and must confine myself to one of his blunders.

  Jack had been jilted in his young days, and hated woman worse than he did poison or rattlesnakes, for he would have sooner taken either than a wife.  His courtship and its catastrophe was thus related by himself.
  "Wal, you shall hear why I hate the hule sex of female women, and I guess nobody hasn't no better cause, cause why, I was a darned fool tew think ther war any truth in the pesky critters.  Wal, when I got perty cumfurtably 'stablished in my bisness, I thought I'd look 'round and see ef I couldn't find a gal ter my likin, and after a while I fell afoul of Prudence Gray - she was a slick gal, and no mistake - but war like all the rest on 'em, mighty clever tew look at, and mighty fine with her gab, and that war all.  She lived down to Dorchester, she did, did Prudence, and what an all fired sight of money I spent for her hire - I haint bin sich a fool sense, no how - tew go and set up o'nights with her - and what for, I should like

I found out Prudence, and squats down close by her, and went at it as hard as any  on 'em.  Wal, byn-by, arter singin a few, and tellin a sight o'stories, some one sings out --

  "A speech from Jack Peak - Jolly Jack.  And the pesky fellers wouldn't be quiet until I consinted, which I didn't dew till Prudence whispered tew me tew go ahead and giv em plenty of gisticerlashun.   So they mounted me onto a bar'l, and I commenced splutterin away somethin I didn't know nothin about, when all on a sudding the head of the barl guv in, and I went ker-swouse, right plump through inter a hul mess o'swill that was inter the darned consarn.  I began to spit and splatter, and they began to larf, and the more I squirmed and spluttered the more they larfed, till, bymby, one on em tuck pity on my disolute condition and extercated me from the nasty stuff, and the way I streaked it hum that night want tew be beat, I tell you."

Wal, as I was sayin; after I got him I sot down and began to consider as how I war tew dew under the carcumstances, and I made up my mind that she would come round yet, and not be so perticular - but she didn't dew nothin of the like, but her brothers did though, and I cotched it agin. 

            "One very cold night boo-roo-re! it makes me shiver tew think on't - they got inter my house some how or nuther, and pullin me out of my bed, they tuck me just as I war - nothin on but my shirt - inter the backyard, and rolled me over and over inter the snow, till I was ennamost dead. After that they tuck me back inter the store and rubbed me down with a gunny bag soaked inn salt and brandy, so that I didn't get over it for a hul month arter; and I guess as how I didn't never go no more to set up with Pru Gray, particular as she was married that very night tew a hamsum feller of Roxbury; and the spree at my house was a kinder windin up o' the ceremoney; and I really believe as how the swill barrl war the beginnin on't."

And then the pesky critter got more wrathy nor afore, and flews at me like a tiger, making my face feel all over like a scotchd herrin, and I had to mizzle agin in a way that war perfectly edifyin and destructio tew all creashun.   Besides losin a considerable grab of hair, half a shirt collar, and a slice of cheek, one side of my tail-coat tail, I mean - war left behind."

Chapter XVIII
[underlined] Life in the Year 1841. 

      Thus far my life has been a series of vicisitudes and misfortunes; yet have I reason to praise my God inasmuch as he has given me many valuable friends and not permited me to be entirely destitute.  In thy hands, Oh, Lord! do I commit myself trusting that in thine own good time thou wilt deliver me from this gal of bitterness and relieve my distress. Amen. 
     [ This paragraph was written on the evening of the 31st of December, 1840 - but the record of the very next day shows how imperfectly I then understood the atributes of true Christian character, and how mistaken I then was as to my relation to Christ.] 
     My Journal having been kept a little more regular for the next two years, and more, I shall transcribe it. 
     Friday, Jany. 1st.1841- Was obliged to remain at home in consequence of a bad cold taken a week previous. Amused myself by reading plays in the "British Drama. Trust the end of the year will not find me so foolishly employed. 
     Sunday, 3rd- Yesterday and to-day passed in the same way as Friday, except that I substituted the Bible for the Drama. 
     Monday, 4th- The weather was exceedingly

110

       "Oh! don't say nothin about that. But I 'spose I must tell the hul. Wal, they - Pru and her man- kept it hangin up over their kitchen fire place with a great card on it - so I'm tell'd by them as seed it- with these words," I (and here Jack chalked on the counter in rude characters.) 
      [underlined] "The tale of Bos(ting) Peak; A short tail of a tailor."
       "Untel one on their dogs got hurt, and they tuck it tew --"
       "To what? Out with it man."
       "Tew tie up his tail, what got smashed."
       "Poor Jack! that was the unkindest cut of all," for it was cur-tailing your property, and retailing it to a dog."
       "Oh! Oh! y-e-s-s: and it en-tailed considerable ridicule upon me; blast their ugly picters!"
       "And you were cut up, I suppose, in detail." 
       "Zack-ly."
       Obtaining  permanent employment in Boston being out of the question I resolved to again try my fortune at the West, and gathering up what I could I left about the middle of November (1840) for New York. On arriving here I found my means were inadequate to pursue my Journey, and was obliged to remain.

113
evening paid Genl. Gaines a visit, not having seen him since I was ten years of age.   Was much surprised to find him so much altered, although in in [sic] good health.  He speaks very slow, and appears taciturn, yet affable.

   Saturday, 9th - Quite warm for the season.  In the morning paid a second visit to Genl. Gaines with my wife, and was agreably entertained by Mrs. Gaines with the particulars of her extraordinary law suit in New Orleans.  In the evening went to hear the General and his lady lecture - he upon National defense, she upon the Horrors of War.   It gave me much pain to see one whom I so much respected so far advanced in his dotage as to make such a pompous display of his person.   How very, very unlike his former self.  How unlike the modest merit and gallant conduct of his earlier days.  How sad that one so honored should be so childish in his last days - yet he certainly has projected a system of defense which, if adopted, might be of great national benefit, and notwithstanding his advanced age he may live to see if partially adopted.
   Monday, 18th.  Still without employment.  Leisure hours since last entry devoted to reading Rollin's Ancient History.   Very cold.
   Tuesday, 19th. - This has been a duplicate

112
disagreable and I remained at home and copied "The Yankee Frolic," a comedy by my dear wife.  Tuesday and Wednesday occupied in the same way.

  Thursday, 7th. - Stormed all day, the wind blowing a gale from S.E.   Toward night news reached the city of the loss of he packet ship Garick, from Liverpool, which went ashore on the Jersey beech.  Passengers and crew all saved.  A novel and pleasing incident occured at the Police office this morning.  A young, fair and blooming little French Girl appeared and entered prosecution against one Cornelius Sebring for the maintainance of a cherub.  The gentleman appeared and acknowledged himself its father, and added voluntary encomiums on the modesty and attractions of the fair sinner, [?resining?] that he might be alowed to make her the amend honorable by taking her to himself for better or for worse.   Both parties being agreed, the Justice united them in the hallowed bands of wedlock and they left the office apparently quite delighted at the happy termination of the sad affair.
  Friday = 8th - Went out for the first time since Christmas, and yet unable to obtain employment.   It is a hard life I lead - but God is the judge of all men ank [sic] knows what is  best for us.  His will be done.  In the

extraordinary.  Throughout the whole discourse he entranced his auditory, receiving the most rapturous applause at its conclusion.

   Thursday, 21st. - At home all day writing.  
   Sunday, 24th. - In the morning attended St. Thomas' Church, and listened to an excellent sermon by Dr. Hawks from Ps. 147.3.  "He healeth the broken in heart, and bindeth up their wounds."  David undoubtedly here refers to the blessed Saviour, whose mission upon earth was to relieve the distressed spirit, and furnish a balm - a sovereign cure - for the suffering heart and dying soul; that whosoever would, should come to the Paradise God has prepared for him from the foundation of the world.   It was the object of this celebrated divine to explain in his discourse, First - The relation his text bore toward the Gospel of Christ, and its perfect harmony with that Gospel; and then, to show the manner in which we are to obtain assistance of the Great Physician in time of trouble in order to obtain perfect bliss in the heavenly mansions where the "weary are at rest."  To show the goodness and mercy of God in providing for us miserable, needy sinners such a safe and heavenly refuge; and finaly to exhort his hearers to apply to that Saviour before it was too late, and seek that happiness which this world can neither give nor take away.  May these admonitions, Oh! Lord! sink deep into the heart of thy

114
of yesterday.  Seeing in the Sun (newspaper) of this morning a notice of a donation to the Bunker Hill monument, I was reminded of an incident which occurred last winter, which contrasts strongly with the pompous announcement referred to.   While passing St. Paul's Church, where a blind begger was seated soliciting alms, I was attracted by the strange conduct of a little sailor boy and was induced to watch him.  He gazed upon the mendicant for some time, his eyes beaming with pity.  At last, turning his back to the passing throng and stealthily selecting a bank note from his pocket book, he approached the old man and watching an opportunity when he thought he was not observed dropped it into the mendicant's hand and hurried on whistling.  What a lesson to those who riot in wealth and daily pass the unfortunate and distressed without bestowing even a [word underlined] look of compassion on them.  What a reproof to those who make an ostentatious display of their charities.  

  Wednesday, 20th. - Snow fell all day.   Went in the evening to hear Mr. Eames lecture on the "Spirit of American History."  He had a large audience and handled his subject with a masterly hand.  His eloquence will certainly compare with the greatest of the age - and although very young his reasoning powers are

117
tal language of the North American Indians, their worship and ceremonies proclaim them descendants of the Israelites.   The Peruvians, Mexicans &c like the Persians, worship many gods, the sun and fire being considered most potent - while the North American Indians acknowledge but one great, good and alwise God, capable of punishing or rewarding them hereafter according as they live in this world.  Like the Egyptians, the former were in the habit of embalming their dead, or in heaping their bones in hecatombs; while the latter place each body in a seperate grave.   The one lived in houses built of brick, the other in tents.   The South Americans sacrifice flesh to their gods whereas the North Americans never do.  Add to these the North American Indian tradition of the flood, of which event they retain an imperfect account; and also another which points to the west as the land of their ancient forefathers, the inference is too strong to be resisted.   My indisposition prevented me from attending the lecture of the Hon. Isaac Hill, on the "Hills of New England," at the Lyceum, last evening.  But as a balm to my disappointment I was given to understand that I lost nothing, as it was a very dull, prosey discourse.  This was unexpected to me, as I have read several articles from the same pen with much satisfaction and instruction.

  Monday, 25. - This morning, between four and five o'clock, a very heavy shock of an earthquake was felt throughout the city, New Jersey and Long Island.   It created considerable alarm among the superstitious, and was so violent  that those walking in the street at the time were obliged to lay hold of whatever was within reach to prevent falling.  The noise accompanying the shocks resembled the rolling of innumerable heavy wagons over the pavement.
   Thursday, 28th. - Have suffered for the last three days from a violent cold, which has confined me, for the most part, to the house, during which time I have been occupied in reading Rollin.   While perusing this work (which I never before read) I have been forcibly struck with the strong analogy between the manners and customs of some of the ancients and the aborigines of North and South America, which confirms a belief already entertained, that the latter were originally from Asia.  The Peruvian form of worship, burying of the dead, style of buildings &c, when discovered by the Spaniards so much resembled the Persian and Egyptian customs as to leave little doubt of their having been derived from these nations; while the orien-

   While boarding at a hotel last summer he repeatedly witnessed the expulsion of a noisy old Frenchman from the house who had been requested not to visit it.   He was a persevering fellow and seemed to care very little for the rude treatment he received.   One afternoon he came in accompanied by an Englishman, and, as usual, was thrust out.  His friend, considering the act as in insult offered to himself, became highly enraged and very abusive.  "If I had," said he, "brought the vilest cur into the room you could not have treated me more scandalously.   Had you hinted to me that the presence of the old gentleman was not agreable I should have taken him away; but as it is - I am not in the habit of receiving an insult."   Mr. S--, who is a wit, in his way, and let no opportunity pass for exercising it upon turning the wrath of the Englishman to account; and with this view instigated a Mr. A--g to reply to his abuse, which he did with such bitter sarcasm that John Bull demanded satisfaction.  "Sir," said he, "since you take upon yourself the responsibility of this insult offered to me, I demand of you that satisfaction due from one gentleman to another under such circumstances."  "Certainly," replied Mr. A--;  "I am always ready to an-

   Friday, 29th - During the morning the city was visited by a brisk snow storm.  It however turned to rain in the course of the afternoon.  At half past nine in the evening a destructive fire broke out in Fulton street consuming two large brick buildings - Nos. 29 & 31.
  Monday, Feby. 1st. - I have suffered much during the last three days from my cold - Yet what is the disease of he body compared to that of the mind?   How bitterly I have been made to feel the want of employment, and my dependance!  It is, nevertheless, human for those who are actively engaged to rail at and censure those who are unfortunate, without lifting a finger in help.   Little do they know the difficulties, perplexities, and misery of him who in penury and want has to stem the current of injustice.  They may call me lazy, and heap upon me all the invectives they can command, God the searcher of all hearts will judge between us and I trust will put it in my power, 'ere long, to falsify their words.
  Tuesday, 2d. - Wrote a note to Mr. Hill in regard to the play "The Yankee Frolic," founded upon the Canada rebellion.  Received an unexpected visit from cousin L.G.S - of Boston  He is one of my favorite cousins.
  Wednesday, 3d  Spent the day with Mr. S--, it being the first time I have left the

His breast heaved violent with emotion, his face turned to ashy paleness and his eyes glared with an idiotic stare.   Mr. S -  rushed up to him - "Fly," said he, "fly for your life.  You are lost if you remain a moment!"   "I cannot fly," he gasped.  "You must fly, for my sake if not for your own.   The Police will certainly hear of this shortly and be here without delay.  Fly, if you wish to preserve your life."   The idea of falling into the hands of the Police, and suffering an ignominious death brought him to his senses and he rushed out the back door in great consternation.   The spectators of the scene, who, throughout the whole, had maintained a serious air, and long melancholly faces, no sooner saw him out than they gave way to a hearty fit of merriment.   But their farce was not yet over - a second scene must be enacted, for they were informed that he was returning.   Mr. A--'s coat, vest and cravat were instantly striped off and he laid out on three chairs with a bandage tied around his head.   A quantity of cranberry juice was procured with which they smeared the bandage and face; and to make the deception still more natural one of the gentlemen

    Thursday, 4th. - This morning at 11 o'clock a fire broke out in No 27½ Hudson St., doing little damage to the building, but burning two children so severely that it is thought that they cannot live.
    Friday, 5th.  A severe pain in the face prevented my going out.  In the evening an eclipse of the moon took place.   It commenced a few minutes pst seven o'clock and was total from half-past eight to half-past nine.
   Saturday, 6th. - This has been a very unprofitable day, inasmuch as I have been too irritable to read.   Man may be placed in many unpleasant and trying circumstances, for he is prone to trouble "as the sparks to fly upwards;" and although it has been my lot to suffer many misfortunes and keen reproach, I have experienced no evil so great as dependence.   The huliliation [sic] I am obliged to submit to is, alone sufficient to depress the mind, but when sneers,

with an Aunt, while in Boston, on various points of religious faith I to-day began a series of letters on the muted points, in fulfillment of a promise made. xxxxxx I shall commence with the doctrine of the Divinity of Christ, and follow upon other points as I shall have oportunity.   To prove that Christ is God I shall not only quote from the New Testament, but also from the Old, which will show the perfect harmony of the Scriptures, and disprove the assertions, that the Old has nothing to do with the doctrines taught in the New Testament.   You will see by the few selections I make the absurdity of such assertions are apparent.   I am thoroughly convinced from the following passages of scripture that Jesus Christ is God, the Creator and Saviur [sic] of the world.

   Compare John I. 1, with Genesis I. 1.  John here declares that the Word (Christ) was God.  Is not this assertion positive enough?  But still stronger texts can be found.  Compare John I, 2 to 14 with Prov. VIII, 22 to 31;  Col. I, 15 to 17 with Gen. I, 26; 1st John, I, 1 with Ps. XXX, 6; John, XVII, 5, with Isaiah, XLIII, 13; Math. I, 24 with Isa. VII, 14; John, VIII, 58 with Exodus, III, 14.  Here we find Jesus assuming the same title with the Father, and by so doing making himself God - for which assertion the Jews took up stones to cast at Him.  Let Unitarians answer satisfactorily the question, "If Christ is not God, how is it that he was before Abraham; or (as the preceding text says)

   Sunday, 7th. - Went to St. Thomas Ch. in the morning.   The sermon was by Dr. Hawks, from Rom. VIII, 13. "For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if ye through the Spirit mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live."    Monday, 8th. - This was the most delightful day we have had this winter.  Spent the day with Samuel and dined at his brother Josiah's
  Tuesday, 9th. - Today Genl. Harrison, the President elect, enters upon his sixty-eighth year.  The morning was warm, clear and delightful; but a snowstorm occurred in the afternoon, snow falling to the depth of three inches.
  Thursday, 11 - This has been a clear but very cold day, with the wind from the west.  Wrote a letter to Genl. Harrison; and received one from my dear mother dated Jany 29 1841, principally containing an account of her marriage, the battle of Brownstown, and the surrender of Detroit.
   Friday, 12th. - Has been the coldest day this winter.   Having had various controversies

   Sunday, 14th - Poverty preventing my purchasing a pair of boots, and the old ones being in a delapidated state I was under the necessity of remaining at home.  Improved my mind by searching the Scripture.
  Wednesday, 17th. - The last two days have been exceedingly monotinous. [sic]  In the evening went to a meeting in the Baptist church in McDougal St.  The Rev. Mr. Waters preached an excellent discourse from Col. III.4.  "When Christ, who is our life, shall appear, then shall we also appear with Him in glory."  From this he pictured the blessed hope set before the saints who continued steadfast in their love and obedience to God, and Jesus Christ - an unreserved reliance upon the mediation and intercessions of the Saviour, and the blessings and happiness of a devout and Godly life.   He drew a strong picture in contrast between the truly evangelical christian and a mere professor, remarking that men often mistook conviction for conversion, and thinking that continual prayer being all-sufficient to secure  their admission into the kingdom of heaven, made all their virtues subservient to it.  "But, my hearers," said he, "if prayer alone were necessary, the damned in hell would not be excluded; for in their torments they continually pray - even for a drop of water to cool their tongues."  He exhorted the

Here we find Isaiah giving Him the title of the "Mighty God, the everlasting Father" - and we have also the evidence of Jesus himself, confirming the Prophets words - "He that hath seen me hath seen the Father." 129

  Sunday, 21st. - Attended the McDougal street Baptist church in the morning and listened to the Rev. Mr. Waters, who preached from the Book of Job, XXIV, 21.  "Acquaint now thyself with him and be at peace;  thereby good shall come unto thee."  He was not so happy on this occasion as on Wednesday evening.   His manner partook too much of the ranting style, and he evidently said all he knew on the former occasion.   Notwithstanding he presented some excellent views upon the glory and happiness attendant upon a thorough acquaintance with Christ.
   Monday, 22d. - The birthday of the father of his country, Genl. George Washington.  What a torrent of thought rushes through the mind on a day like this.   It comes with many hallowed associations clustering about it, while it invites fresh recollections of he events in the life of that great man connected, as they are, with the history of our country.
  Tuesday, 23d - Applied for two situations and got neither.  Wrote a letter to the Hon. A. S. Porter of Michigan for his influence in obtaining ing [sic] an appointment under Government.
   Wednesday, 24th. - Has been a very cloudy damp day, and I have suffered much from rheumatism.  Wrote aunt J-- the following letter on the doctrine of Judgment.
   In my first letter I endeavored to prove

sinner in eloquent pathos to flee from the wrath to come, and lay hold of the hope set before them; and warned the aged christian against dampening the ardor of the young convert by rebuking him for not seeing every truth as clearly as he;  at the same time he endeavored to instil into the mind of the latter the necessity of close application to the study of the Bible, and the error of trying to grasp the whole treasure at once, and, as is frequently the case, setting their opinions in opposition to those who have made the Scripture the study of their lives, and even going so far as to dictate to the ministers of God.   He also censured very severely those persons who would make religion consist in long faces, gloomy thoughts and demure conduct, justly remarking, "If there is not happiness in religion, where can it be found?"  His whole discourse was truly evangelical and happily adapted to draw the transgressor to God, as well as to renew the drooping spirits of the professor, and bind him closer to his Saviour.

   Saturday, 20th.- Being in want of a vest and unable to purchase one I have been engaged for the last three days in putting my mechanical genius to the test, and have succeeded in making quite a comfortable garment.

He does not say it is the vices and virtues He is thus to seperate, [sic] but all nations individually:  And Daniel says, "some to everlasting life, and some to everlasting shame and contempt."  He here speaks of persons, not of virtues and vices, who are accepted or rejected according as the gifts of God are received and acted upon.  How rediculous [sic] the very  idea of interpreting these passages in the Universalist light - and yet we must give them credit for the ingenuity they evince in their arguments, and the dreadful manner in which their brains must be tortured in order to bring forth such an abortion.  That there is to be a day when all nations and people will be gathered together, both the quick and he dead, and judged according to the deeds done in  the body, none but the hardened sinner and infidel will deny.  It is not a new doctrine, "created by priest-craft."  Neither was it new to the Apostles, for, although the Saviour opened their eyes still more on the subject, that they might understand it better and be more competent to instruct others in all things necessary to the salvation of man, they undoubtedly believed it before, for Moses, David and the Prophets had not only believed but taught it. 130
the divinity of Christ, and show the absurdity of the Unitarian doctrine as compared with Scripture.  I shall now, by selections from the Gospels, Epistles and Prophets give the reasons for my belief in a final judgment.  It has been asserted by Universalists, that at the judgment, it is the impurities which are to be seperated [sic] from the purities of man's nature, and that the first will be destroyed, while the latter will secure his entrance into heaven.  Let us see what Jesus says about it, and we will see how rediculous such a doctrine will appear when compared with His word.  Is it possible that He would clothe such an important matter in such mystery as these visionaries would have us believe?  No.  Praise be to His name, He has made his language so simple and comprehensive in regard to this subject that none but visionaries and over wise people attempt to pervert His words and make them of none effect.    Compare Math. XXV, 31 to 46 with Dan. VII, 13, 26, 27; Ps. CXV, 15; IX, 7, 8; Prov. XIX, 17; Dan. XXII, 2.  Jude, 14, 15 with Zech. XIV, 5;  Rom. XIV, 10 and Math. X, 15 with Ps. I, 4; 2 Cor. V, 10 and Heb. IX, 27 with Ecl. XII, 14; Acts, XVII, 32 with Ps. XCVI, 10.

133
a widely spread as Christ's fame was, He should not be known.  This he explained by stating - first, that the national predjudice of the Jews would not permit them to believe, favored as they had been by God, that the barrier, or partition, between them and the Gentiles should be broken down and all be admitted to the same dispensation of God's grace.  Secondly - They were unwilling to relinquish the ceremonies so long established among them.  Thirdly - The requirements made by Christ were opposed to their selfish interests; and lastly - They were not willing, by the entire surrender of their hearts, "to make themselves fools that they might become wise."  He then compared worldly minded persons of the present day to the Jews; pointing out the close resemblance between them as connected with all their transactions - touching upon the political slate of our country, in the most feeling and eloquent manner, and although he repudiated the idea of the establishment of any particular church, upon the principle that it would be the death stroke to true Christianity in the country, he said it was yet absolutely necessary for its welfare that its proceedings should be founded upon Christian principles, and that if we ever had to mourn its downfall, it would be in consequence of the wrath of God for the sins of the people.  He concluded by an appeal to sinners, exhorting

132
tions of St. John, we all know, gives a glowing and terrible picture of this "great day of the Lord."

  I am also led to believe, by Scripture, which I shall quote hereafter upon another subject, that our souls and bodies will be reunited at that day, and although "this mortal shall put on immortality, yet in our flesh we shall see God."  This is more strongly impressed upon my mind from the fact that all will not taste death before that day, but, in the language of the Bible, those who remain upon earth will be caught up into the clouds to meet Christ when He shall appear.  I deem it unnecessary to say more upon this subject.  May God give us all more knowledge, and a right understanding that we may clearly see the truth revealed in His holy word, and make us wise unto salvation.

republic.  May blessings attend the administrations of our chosen chief, and may God give him grace so to use his power that the clouds that now hang over us may be dispelled, and the bright one of prosperity again shed its rays over the land, distributing its benefits equally over all. Oh, Father in heaven! many evil thoughts and inordinate desires have caused me to go astray from the paths of righteousness.   My heart is continually evil, there is no good thought within me.    Friday, 5th. - After two weeks of warm pleasant weather it has changed to cold and damp.
  Saturday, 6th. - The pleasant weather of the past week gave place to a brisk snow storm during this morning, which changed to rain in the course of the afternoon.   In the evening and throughout the night the wind blew a gale from the northwest.
   Sunday, 7th. - Attended St. Thomas' church.  A stranger preached, but in so low a tone I could not hear his text, or keep the thread of his discourse, which was ardently aimed at infidelity.
  Monday, 8th. - A cloudy, cold day.  Wrote a letter to my dear mother.
  Wednesday, 10th.  Stormed all day, wrote letters to Genl. W. Scott, Genl. E. P. Gaines and Hon. A. T. Porter.

  Monday, March, 1st. - March comes in with the smile of gladness upon the face of nature - serene and lovely.  How different it is with my prospects in life!  Darkness covers them; and the uncertainty of the future chases happiness and joy from my mind.   True it is - "That hope deferred maketh the heart sick."  Yet in God will I put my trust, that He may forget my sins and deliver me from the bitterness of this trial. [Oh! how wickedly I forsook Him when He did send me prosperity.]
   Tuesday, 2d. - Received three letters from Maumu; from uncle Charles, my dear mother and sister  Marion; the first of which I answered
  Wednesday, 3d. - The steamship President arrived from Liverpool at quarter past eleven o'clock A.M.  George P. Putnam came a passenger, and looks like the same old six pence.
   Thursday, 4th. - This day Genl. W. H. Harrison takes the Presidential chair, and the little fox Marin Van Buren retires to his cabbage plantation at Kinderhook.   Saturday, 13th. - At twelve o'clock M of this day George P. Putnam was married to Victoriine Haven by Mr. Dewey of the Unitarian meeting house, Broadway.  My dear wife wrote a beautiful poem suitable to the occasion and presented it to the bride.

for the truth that is in us," I shall follow the plan laid down in my former letters and furnish from the Bible my grounds of belief. Of the doctrine of future rewards and punishments, there are three or four distinct classes of evidence to be found in Scripture--In treating of which I shall begin with that which throws the strongest light on the subject; and conclude by endeavoring to analize the pretended foundation of the Universalists' creed. You are perhaps aware of the little opportunity I have had for theological research, having confined myself entirely to the study of the Bible, and drawn my conclusions from its pages. I have read no other book on any of the subjects of which i treat, and all I knew in relations to the creeds of the sects mentioned has been gathered wholly from the lips of persons processing those beliefs. The first proofs I shall adduce treat more particularly of the punishment of the wicked after Judgment, which we all know takes place after death, which I have shown in a former letter. Other points will be discussed hereafter.

of Miss Arabella Popingham's guests, and how proud she felt as she paraded through the room and whispered to one and another of her acquaintances.  General conversation was out of the question.   Miss Arabella had no conversational powers, and she left her guests to amuse themselves as they could, while she replied in simpering smiles to the compliments of the whiskered and moustached dandies who always fluttered around her; for, though she was a blue and a savante, she was not insensible to flattery.

   "I have just finished reading your "Essays" said she, to a young gentleman named Landon.  "I really think them superior to those of Charles Lamb.  Mr. Topland, you never write  verses, I believe, except when you are in love - but Mr. Tinfoil writes enough for you and himself too.  What a sweet thing that was to "Laun-Matilda."  Mr. Tinfoil bowed.  "And then the sonnet to Angelina Fortescue.  She is never tired of reading it.  Mr. Straws, your last poem made me laugh heartily.   You are such a wit I shall be afraid of you," - shaking her finger at him "Don't show me up in any of your lyrics - if you do I shall cut you.  Ah! Mr. Pryer," - as she observed that gentleman peeking into her private album - "I cannot allow you the privilege of prying into my secrets: - and thus she rattled on from one to another.
